slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.content:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  1. Distinguish between generative and discriminative models
  2. Understand autoencoder and VAE architectures
  3. Explain GAN architecture and training dynamics
  4. Implement image-to-image translation
  5. Apply style transfer techniques

slides.title: Introduction to Generative Models
slides.content: Creating new data from learned distributions

slides.title: Generative vs Discriminative
slides.content:
Discriminative
Learn P(y|x)
Classification, regression
Generative
Learn P(x) or P(x|y)
Sample new data

slides.title: Latent Space Concept
slides.content: Latent Space: Compressed representation where similar items are close together. Meaningful directions in latent space correspond to semantic attributes.

knowledgeCheck.question: Why is the latent space important in generative models?
knowledgeCheck.answer: The latent space provides a compressed, structured representation of data. Points in latent space can be sampled to generate new data, and interpolating between points creates smooth transitions. Well-organized latent spaces also allow for semantic manipulation.

slides.title: Autoencoders
slides.content: Learning compressed representations

slides.title: Autoencoder Architecture
slides.content:
Autoencoder: Learn identity function through bottleneck.

  • Encoder: Compress input to latent code
  • Decoder: Reconstruct from latent code
  • Loss: Reconstruction error (MSE)

slides.title: Variational Autoencoders
slides.content: Probabilistic latent representations

slides.title: VAE Architecture
slides.content:
VAE: Encode to distribution (μ, σ), not single point.
Enables generation by sampling from latent distribution.

slides.title: VAE Encoder
slides.content:
Encoder outputs parameters of latent distribution:

$$q(z|x) = \mathcal{N}(\mu(x), \sigma(x)^2)$$

slides.title: VAE Sampling (Reparameterization)
slides.content:
Reparameterization Trick:

$$z = \mu + \sigma \cdot \epsilon, \quad \epsilon \sim \mathcal{N}(0, 1)$$

Enables backpropagation through sampling operation.

knowledgeCheck.question: Why is the reparameterization trick necessary in VAEs?
knowledgeCheck.answer: Sampling from a distribution is not differentiable. The reparameterization trick moves the stochasticity to an input (ε) so the model can backpropagate gradients through μ and σ, enabling end-to-end training.

slides.title: VAE Decoder
slides.content: Decoder: Maps latent code z back to image space. Generation: sample z ~ N(0,1), decode to image.

slides.title: GANs
slides.content: Generative Adversarial Networks

slides.title: GAN Architecture
slides.content:
GAN: Two networks in competition.

  • Generator: Creates fake images from noise
  • Discriminator: Distinguishes real from fake

slides.title: GAN Generator
slides.content: Generator Goal: Learn to produce images indistinguishable from real data. Maps random noise z to image space.

slides.title: GAN Discriminator
slides.content: Discriminator Goal: Correctly classify images as real or fake. Provides learning signal to generator.

slides.title: GAN Game Theory
slides.content:
Minimax Game:

$$\min_G \max_D \mathbb{E}[\log D(x)] + \mathbb{E}[\log(1 - D(G(z)))]$$

G minimizes, D maximizes. Nash equilibrium when D can't distinguish.

slides.title: GAN Training Dynamics
slides.content:
Alternating training:
  1. Train D on real + fake (labeled)
  2. Train G to fool D
  3. Repeat

slides.title: Mode Collapse
slides.content:
Mode Collapse: Generator produces limited variety. Only generates samples that easily fool discriminator.

Solutions: Wasserstein loss, spectral normalization, progressive training.

knowledgeCheck.question: What is mode collapse and why is it problematic?
knowledgeCheck.answer: Mode collapse occurs when the generator learns to produce only a few types of outputs that fool the discriminator, ignoring the full diversity of the real data distribution. The generated samples lack variety and don't represent the true data distribution.

slides.title: Training Tips
slides.content:
• Use batch normalization
  • Leaky ReLU in discriminator
  • Adam optimizer (low learning rate)
  • Label smoothing
  • Balance G and D training

slides.title: VAE vs GAN
slides.content:
VAE
Stable training
Blurry outputs
Explicit density
GAN
Harder to train
Sharp outputs
Implicit density

slides.content: Real-world generative applications

slides.title: Generation Examples
slides.content: Faces, art, objects generated by modern GANs

slides.title: Latent Interpolation
slides.content: Interpolation: Smooth transitions between generated images by interpolating in latent space.

slides.title: Conditional Generation
slides.content: Conditional GAN (cGAN): Control generation with class labels or other conditions. Generate specific types of images on demand.

slides.title: Image-to-Image Translation
slides.content:
pix2pix, CycleGAN:
Sketch → Photo
Day → Night
Horse → Zebra
Satellite → Map

slides.title: Style Transfer
slides.content:
Neural Style Transfer: Apply artistic style of one image to content of another.

Minimize: Content loss + Style loss (Gram matrices)

slides.title: Applications Overview
slides.content: Generative models: art, entertainment, data augmentation, super-resolution

slides.title: Implementation
slides.content:
import torch
import torch.nn as nn

class Generator(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self, latent_dim=100):
        super().__init__()
        self.model = nn.Sequential(
            nn.Linear(latent_dim, 256),
            nn.LeakyReLU(0.2),
            nn.Linear(256, 512),
            nn.LeakyReLU(0.2),
            nn.Linear(512, 784),
            nn.Tanh()
        )
    
    def forward(self, z):
        return self.model(z).view(-1, 1, 28, 28)

# Generate images
z = torch.randn(16, 100)
fake_images = generator(z)

slides.content: Key Takeaways

slides.title: Key Takeaways
slides.content:
1. Autoencoders: Learn compressed representations via reconstruction
  2. VAE: Probabilistic latent space enables generation
  3. GAN: Generator vs discriminator adversarial training
  4. Mode collapse: Major GAN training challenge
  5. Applications: Image generation, translation, style transfer
  6. Future: Diffusion models, large-scale generation
